intro: Oxymeris tetraquetra, commonly known as the four-angled mangrove, is a species of flowering plant in the family Rhizophoraceae. It is a small evergreen tree or shrub characterized by its quadrangular stems and thick, waxy leaves. The plant is native to coastal regions of Southeast Asia and is adapted to saline and waterlogged soils. It plays an important ecological role in mangrove ecosystems by stabilizing shorelines and providing habitat for various marine and terrestrial species. Oxymeris tetraquetra is also valued for its timber and has been used in traditional medicine in some cultures.
